header.title: The Scroll of Set - April 1991 - Volume XVII-2

central_thesis: The core philosophy emphasizes a rigorous, self-directed, and conscious approach to personal evolution (Xeper) within the Left-Hand Path of Setian magic. This involves cultivating mental discipline, understanding subjective reality, and engaging in deliberate transformative processes, often through structured 'rites of passage' and practical magical techniques, while explicitly rejecting passive or superficial occult methods.

structure_content.summary: This article posits that the human mind's capabilities are limitless, bounded only by imagination. It advocates for simple, quiet mental exercises to empty thoughts, concentrate on inner feelings, and cultivate perception through the 'mind's eye.' The goal is to attain control to project will under any circumstance, allowing the Initiate to create personal audio/visual environments. It distinguishes this self-contained magical ability of the Elect from superficial 'play witch' practices, emphasizing continuous practice, precision, and the conscious evolution of mind and will as the path to the 'higher self' and immortality.

structure_content.chapter_title: [2] When the Stars Come Right Again
structure_content.summary: This article explores the integration of Lovecraftian Mythos into Setian workings. It views mundane awareness as protective ignorance, with science as a potential exception, but highlights humanity's general inability to accept 'truth.' The Mythos' themes, like 'gates' and alien gods (Nyarlathotep), are interpreted as metaphors for breaking horizons and exploring the unknown. Practical suggestions include studying human responses to the unknown, comparing cultures, and using 'alien technology' (lighting, optical illusions, electronic sound, plasma globes) to detach spatial/temporal awareness in magical workings.

This article outlines a three-phase practical system for controlling dream states. The first phase, dream recall, involves consistent daily record-keeping. The second is lucidity, learning to recognize one is dreaming and remaining conscious within the dream. The third, dream control, is the ability to consciously create and interact within the dream environment. The author highlights common challenges like false awakenings and recommends specific books for further study.

This article discusses Astral projection from a Setian perspective, focusing on the distinction between objective and subjective universes. It asserts that Astral experience is fundamentally subjective, even if details appear to corroborate external locations. The author warns against mistaking subjective experiences for objective reality, attributing such insistence to a 'residual fear of extinction.' It encourages continued research and experimentation in Astral projection but stresses relying on personal empiricism over preconceived notions and understanding that it is a tool within the broader context of Xeper and initiation.

This is a report on the first annual gathering of Temple of Set Initiates in Brunswick, Georgia. It describes discussions on topics such as 'The Word Runa,' the Temple's degree system, and 'B-grade horror movies.' A key event was the performance of a rite, 'The Manifestation of our Setian Essence,' which included formal Recognitions for members. The conclave served as an opportunity for Setians to 'recharge batteries' and meet face-to-face, emphasizing community and shared input.

structure_content.chapter_title: [6] Thresholds and Alchemy: Rites of Passage in Initiation
structure_content.summary: This article analyzes rites of passage as powerful tools for self-transformation within Setian Initiation. It defines the 'threshold' as the essential structure of these rites, applicable to various cultural practices (marriage, military training, secret societies). A threefold model is presented: preliminal (separation from old status), liminal (transition, undefined status, often involving tests/humiliations), and postliminal (incorporation into new status). This mechanism is compared to alchemical transformation, where substances break down (preliminal), exist in limbo (liminal chaos), and recombine (postliminal). The article offers practical suggestions for designing personal rites of passage, emphasizing objective challenges, acquisition of hidden knowledge, territorial passage, separation, celebration, and symbolic thresholds.

A short, evocative piece using dragon imagery to symbolize deeper magical perceptions and states. It contrasts the 'hearing' of young dragons, who perceive meaning through sound, with the 'seeing' of older dragons, who understand the value of not being seen. This suggests a progression in magical awareness from direct sensory input to a more subtle, non-visible apprehension of reality, implying a preference for internal and subtle forms of perception over overt, external displays.

This article conducts a deep analysis of the name 'MehenPetTha,' a High Priest of Set, mentioned in the 'Book of Coming Forth by Night.' It interprets the name as 'The man who rends Mehen,' signifying someone who breaks the natural order by 'rending' the serpent god Mehen, who protects ordered existence from chaos. This act symbolizes opening the veil to the 'non-natural' and actively seeking communion with Set, God of the Outer Places. The analysis traces MehenPetTha's initiation through the five angles of the Word of Set, from receiving the Word to systematizing knowledge and proclaiming it, marking a fundamental shift in the Setian priesthood towards active, individual initiation and a conscious engagement with the Unknown. His actions are tied to historical changes in ancient Egypt, demonstrating how magic impacts cultural and political forces, and underscoring the global consequences of the 'Word of Set.'

This brief article announces the formation of the Nyarlathotep Pylon in California. It identifies Nyarlathotep (the Crawling Chaos) as the 'neter of dark knowledge and sinister arcane arts & sciences' within the Lovecraftian mythos, symbolizing 'protean adaptiveness and infinite ability to change.' The pylon's purpose is to provide members with tools for creating significant, measurable, constructive, willed change in their lives, inviting Setians to join in 'nameless rites' and 'fathoming the mysteries of the Abyss.'

key_concepts.definition: The core principle of Setian magic, representing individual self-evolution and becoming. It implies a transformative process from a prior state (e.g., apelike creatures to humans, or humans to other forms) and requires conscious, deliberate effort.

Individuals who have attained a 'higher self' through self-directed evolution, possessing self-contained magical abilities derived from a refined will and advanced perception, capable of effective workings without external ritualistic aids.

A state of mental discipline achieved through quiet meditation and concentration on inner feelings, enabling an Initiate to empty thoughts, perceive with the 'mind's eye,' and gain precise control over their will for projection.

A fundamental Setian differentiation between internal reality (subjective) and external reality (objective). The Astral experience is considered inherently subjective, and true magical understanding involves acknowledging this distinction rather than conflating internal visions with external facts.

Structured sequences of experiences designed for self-transformation, marking a symbolic change in identity or cultural status. Unlike conventional rites, Setian rites are consciously chosen, self-directed, and serve as 'weapons' for the Black Magician's evolution.

The essential structural phase within a rite of passage, characterized by a transitional, undefined status for the participant (betwixt and between old and new categories). This phase, often involving tests or humiliations, is analogous to the chaotic breakdown and recombination phase in alchemical transformation.

A historical/magical figure, High Priest of Set, whose name ('the man who rends Mehen') symbolizes breaking the natural order and actively seeking communion with Set. His initiation through the 'Word of Set' represents a paradigm shift in Setian priesthood towards active, individual-driven transformation and engagement with the Unknown.

A specific revelation or teaching, the 'first' recipient of which was MehenPetTha. Its proclamation by Setian priests brought about significant historical and cultural changes, demonstrating its 'raw power' and global consequence in reshaping human consciousness and interaction with the 'hidden'.

Interpreted as the 'neter of dark knowledge and sinister arcane arts & sciences' from Lovecraftian mythos, symbolizing 'protean adaptiveness and infinite ability to change.' It represents a dynamic force for willed transformation and the exploration of the Abyss within a Setian context.

An individual engaged in conscious self-directed evolution (Xeper) through magical practice, who understands and operates within the machinery of objective and subjective universes, assimilating experiences without offending critical sensibility, and utilizing rites of passage as tools for transformation.

practical_system.description: The practical system revolves around conscious, self-directed transformation (Xeper) through internal and external magical work. It emphasizes developing mental discipline to control thought and project will, understanding the subjective nature of internal experiences (e.g., Astral projection, dreams), and constructing personal 'rites of passage' for deliberate identity shifts. The system encourages rigorous self-empiricism, intellectual analysis, and a rejection of passive, pre-packaged 'magic.'
tools: UV-sensitive paint and black lights (for creating 'floating' geometric structures in ritual spaces).
Industrial and synthesizer music, pure sweep tones, atonal mixes (for Lovecraftian workings).
Negative ion generators (for chamber atmosphere in Lovecraftian rites).
Plasma globes, light ropes, strobes, laser-light displays (as 'mad scientist toys' to detach awareness).
Mirrors suspended in radial patterns (for multiple reflections in ritual chambers).
rituals: Mind-emptying/Concentration exercises: Sitting quietly, emptying thoughts, concentrating on inner feelings and sensations to perceive with the 'mind's eye.'
Dream control: A three-phase discipline involving daily dream recall, developing lucidity (knowing one is dreaming), and actively controlling the dream environment.

Personal rites of passage: Designing and undergoing structured transformative experiences, incorporating elements like objective challenges, acquisition of hidden knowledge, territorial passage, ritualized separation, and ceremonial celebration. These are divided into preliminal (separation), liminal (transition/tests), and postliminal (incorporation).

Lovecraftian Workings: Using specific aesthetic elements (industrial/synthesizer music, 'hair-prickling atonal mixes,' strange rhythms) and 'alien technology' to disrupt spatial/temporal awareness and approach the unknown.
Recognitions: Formal ceremonies marking advancements in initiation within the Temple of Set, such as those described at the Georgia-I Conclave.

relevant_quotes.text: "But the spaces of the mind are a new dimension. Space extends to infinity outwards, the mind stretches to infinity inwards."

"Attainment of the higher self can be accomplished only by the conscious and deliberate evolution of our minds and wills to infinite levels of unbounded and ever increasing perception, imagination, and ability."
"We live on a placid island of ignorance in the midst of black seas of infinity, and it was not meant that we should voyage far..."

"The magical abilities of the Elect are completely self-contained within the will. They are as effective in the middle of the day on a crowded bus as they are in the silence and darkness of the ritual chamber."
"The bottom line remains the same: The experience of the Astral is always subjective, corroborating details brought back by Astral travelers notwithstanding."

"The Setian concept of two co-existing universes, each influencing the other by what tentatively might be described as 'resonance' via a Magical Link, is the only metaphysical theory that avoids the psychic schizophrenia inherent in other magical systems."
"In Initiation, the conscious will of the self is the source, means, and recipient of transformation."
"Mehen is a serpent god in the Tuat...One who would rend Mehen would be someone who opened the veil to something outside the natural order."

critical_analysis.relevance: This collection of articles is highly relevant to Western Esotericism, particularly within the context of the Temple of Set and its Left-Hand Path philosophy. It provides an in-depth, internal perspective on core Setian concepts like Xeper, subjective/objective reality, and initiation. The discussions on 'mind control,' 'rites of passage,' and the interpretation of Lovecraftian mythos and historical figures (MehenPetTha) demonstrate a sophisticated and distinct magical system that emphasizes individual will, conscious transformation, and rigorous intellectual analysis, moving beyond mere ceremonialism or passive mysticism. The practical advice on dream control and personal rite construction offers actionable insights for practitioners.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience is primarily Initiates and practitioners within the Temple of Set or those exploring advanced Left-Hand Path philosophies. It assumes a foundational understanding of occult principles and Setian terminology, making it less accessible to complete beginners. Academic researchers in esotericism would find it valuable for understanding the internal discourse and operational philosophy of a modern magical order, especially its distinctions from other traditions (e.g., RHP, New Age).
